qas.question: When was Switzerland's Federal Constitution adopted?
When was a new Constitution adopted in Switzerland?
How many main governing bodies are on the federal level in Switzerland?
What is the legislative body of the Swiss government called?
What is the executive body of the Swiss government called?

context: The Federal Constitution adopted in <a0_0>1848<a0_0/> is the legal foundation of the modern federal state. It is among the oldest constitutions in the world. A new Constitution was adopted in <a1_0>1999<a1_0/>, but did not introduce notable changes to the federal structure. It outlines basic and political rights of individuals and citizen participation in public affairs, divides the powers between the Confederation and the cantons and defines federal jurisdiction and authority. There are <a2_0>three<a2_0/> main governing bodies on the federal level: the <a3_0>bicameral parliament<a3_0/> (legislative), the <a4_0>Federal Council<a4_0/> (executive) and the Federal Court (judicial).
